name: Goose
summary: The most 'boring' protocol in the stack — and that's exactly why it's valuable. Born inside Block (Square, Cash App) as production infrastructure, Goose is a local-first agent runtime built on MCP. Its 'ordinariness' makes it the neutral reference implementation that AAIF needs. Like Kubernetes was to containers, Goose aims to be the boring-but-essential execution layer for agents. Low danger because it's explicit, auditable, and deliberately un-opinionated.

feedbackLoop.note: Local-first design means all actions visible on user's machine. CLI + desktop app provide full transparency.

edgeCases.note: Clean extension model via MCP. Modular plugin system with clear boundaries.

ambiguity.note: Tool calls are explicit JSON. Actions are logged and traceable.

redundancy.note: Competes with ElizaOS, LangGraph, AutoGen, CrewAI for the 'agent framework' space.

nesting.note: Flat: user → agent → extensions. No recursive agent chains by default.

exitCost.note: Open source, Apache licensed. Local-first means no vendor lock-in. Low switching cost.

identityPenetration.note: Low. Developers see it as plumbing. No tribal identity forming around Goose.

agencyPreservation.note: User controls which extensions load, which model to use, what actions are allowed.

controlInvisibility.note: Deliberately transparent. Local execution means no hidden cloud processing.

crisisMindset.note: No urgency narrative. Block framed it as infrastructure donation, not competitive necessity.
